scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The diary is arranged by interview and visit. George K. Strode is a director of the International Health Division (IHD). The IHD continues its program interests in malaria, respiratory diseases, typhus fever and yellow fever. The Division’s subordinate interests include mental hygiene, syphilis, nutrition and tuberculosis. The IHD also promotes public health education with fellowships and travel grants. Strode received program updates from staff members and interviews professionals in the field of public health.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The diary contains comments on the visited sites regarding public health education and facilities. Includes a list of organizations visited.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The diary is arranged by interview and visit. Mary Tennant is a special member of the International Health Division stationed at the Paris Office. She travels around Europe talking with professionals in the field of public health nursing. The diary documents nursing fellowships, public health nursing education and research in public health.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The diary is arranged by interview and visit. Mary Tennant working from the Paris Office and travelling around Europe is a special member of the International Health Division. The diary focuses on nursing fellowships and nursing education survey.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The diary is arranged by interview and visit. Mary Tennant working from the Paris Office and travelling around Europe is a special member of the International Health Division. The diary focuses on nursing fellowships and nursing education survey.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A brief diary of Mary Tennant travels to Panama to survey nursing training and local public health facilities.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The 1936 diary includes Mary Tennant's surveys of public health education, facilities and general impressions of state and local nursing in East Asia and South America.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: 5 pages. Foreign visits indexed by place only and not by names of individuals.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The diary is arranged according to interview and visit and documents Mary Tennant’s talks with professionals in the field of public health. During 1937, Tennant surveys public health education, gives her impressions of nursing education and public health nursing in China, and discusses nursing fellowships. Included in the diary is a proposed outline of a health center program for Japan.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: 11 pages. Schedule of visits made by Mary Tennant; Index of interviewees.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The diary is arranged according to interview and visit and documents Mary Tennant’s talks with professionals in the field of public health. The focus of the International Health Division in which Mary Tennant is a staff member is disease prevention and investigation of diseases important to public health. The diary details her impressions of public health nursing in Chicago, a cooperative plan for the preparation of public health nurses and the creation of a nursing training project.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The diary is arranged according to interview and visit and documents Mary Tennant’s talks with professionals in the field of public health. The focus of the International Health Division in which Mary Tennant is a staff member is disease prevention and investigation of diseases important to public health. The diary surveys nursing education and public health nursing in the United States and Canada, her attendance at a nursing education conference and discussions regarding nursing fellows.

scopecontent.head: SCope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The diary is arranged according to interview and visit and documents Mary Tennant’s talks with professionals in the field of public health. The focus of the International Health Division in which Mary Tennant is a staff member is disease prevention and investigation of diseases important to public health. The IHD withdraws from various cooperative health undertakings in Europe and focuses efforts on South America and East Asia. The diary details Tennant’s impressions of nursing education and public health on her travels.

The focus of the International Health Division in which Mary Tennant is a staff member is disease prevention and investigation of diseases important to public health. Tennant travels to India to survey various public health center facilities. The diary details her impressions of public health nursing and recommendations for nursing improvements with India collaborating with the Rockefeller Foundation.

The focus of the International Health Division in which Mary Tennant is a staff member is disease prevention and investigation of diseases important to public health. Tennant travels to South America and gives her impressions of nursing in Rio De La Plata and Andean Region.

The focus of the International Health Division in which Mary Tennant is a staff member is disease prevention and investigation of diseases important to public health. Tennant travels to South America to survey nursing education, public health facilities and to administer proposals for public health nursing. The diary also includes a proposed nursing education fund for Iran.

The focus of the International Health Division in which Mary Tennant is a staff member is disease prevention and investigation of diseases important to public health. The diary details the Rockefeller Foundation nursing program in Brazil and fellowships. The diary includes, “Report of Poliomyelitis Epidemic, 1944 Quito, Ecuador.”

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: 19 pages.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The diary is arranged according to interview and visit and documents Mary Tennant’s talks with professionals in the field of public health. The focus of the International Health Division in which Mary Tennant is a staff member is disease prevention and investigation of diseases important to public health. In 1945, Tennant becomes an assistant director of the IHD. The diaries includes public health facilities and school tours, various diaries of South American travels to survey access and promote local and state public health nursing programs. Tennant also travels to Europe and documents a tuberculosis survey in Iceland, nursing education in Sweden and Norway and reports on public health work in Finland.

scopecontent.p: 21 pages.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The diary is arranged according to interview and visit and documents Mary Tennant’s talks with professionals in the field of public health. The focus of the International Health Division in which Mary Tennant is a staff member is disease prevention and investigation of diseases important to public health. Tennant travels to Europe to survey hospital accommodations in Prague, outline a program of public health and social work study and report on nursing in Czechoslovakia during World War II and the occupation.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: 25 pages.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The diary is arranged according to interview and visit and documents Mary Tennant’s talks with professionals in the field of public health. The focus of the International Health Division in which Mary Tennant is a staff member is disease prevention and investigation of diseases important to public health. Tennant travels to Asia and South America. The diary details a survey of the Rockefeller Foundation Indian public health program, field studies of public health nursing in China Japan and Korea. The present status of former Rockefeller Foundation nursing fellows is included as well.

The focus of the International Health Division in which Mary Tennant is a staff member is disease prevention and investigation of diseases important to public health. Tennant travels to South America to survey public health programs, facilities and infrastructure. She is also involved the selection of nursing fellows and discusses Rockefeller Foundation schools of nursing and public health education programs.

The focus of the International Health Division in which Mary Tennant is a staff member is disease prevention and investigation of diseases important to public health. Tennant travels to Europe and South America to survey public health programs, facilities and infrastructure. She attends various public health conferences and receives updates on Rockefeller Foundation nursing fellows. The diary includes, “Study on the Schools of Nursing in Latin America.”

The focus of the International Health Division in which Mary Tennant is a staff member is disease prevention and investigation of diseases important to public health. Tennant travels to India to survey nursing education. She also travels to Iran to survey the region for collaboration with the Rockefeller Foundation to development a comprehensive nursing program. She is updated with the present status of nursing fellows as well.

The diary details the Rockefeller Foundation collaboration with the University of Heidelberg’s School of Nursing, the Family Study, the Soissons project, and reports on nursing in Italy.

scopecontent.head: SCope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: 1917 Index; 4 pages

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Organized according to interview and visit, Vincent talks to various professionals in the field of public health and discusses projects and proposals. As President of the Rockefeller Foundation he steers the focus toward supporting the war effort and making the world a better place through public health funding. The 1917 diary includes the China Medical Board developing a comprehensive medical system in China, the International Health Board focusing on preventive medicine, and camp and community plans for the welfare of American soldiers. Includes Memorandum to Members of the Executive Committee. Washington Interviews, May 26, 1917; and Memorandum of an interview with M. Hovelacque, A Member of the French Commission, at the Plaza Hotel, Made Tuesday, May 29, 1917.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: 1918 Index; 5 pages

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Organized according to interview and visit, Vincent talks to various professionals in the field of public health and discusses projects and proposals. As President of the Rockefeller Foundation he steers the focus toward supporting the war effort and making the world a better place through public health funding. The 1918 diary documents Vincent overseeing and getting updates on Rockefeller Foundation projects from various other officers. A focus of this diary is the war effort particularly concerning war camps. Includes: Memorandum of a Conference Held at 61 Broadway, monday Afternoon March 25, 1918 at 3pm.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: 1919 Index; 5 pages

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Organized according to interview and visit, Vincent talks to various professionals in the field of public health and discusses projects and proposals. As President of the Rockefeller Foundation he steers the focus toward supporting the war effort and making the world a better place through public health funding. The 1919 diary documents Vincent overseeing and getting updates on Rockefeller Foundation projects from various other officers, compiling of a hookworm bibliography, and a trip to the Far East to survey and tour medical education and public health facilities in Asia. He oversees construction of Peking Union Medical College.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: 1920 Index; 6 pages

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Organized according to interview and visit, Vincent talks to various professionals in the field of public health and discusses projects and proposals. As President of the Rockefeller Foundation he handles the institutional and administrative duties of the Rockefeller Foundation, International Health Board and China Medical Board. The 1920 diary documents Vincent's trip to Canada to oversee and start the Canadian medical education program, further discussions of Peking Union Medical College, and its disease research and preventive programs in tuberculous and yellow fever.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: 1921 Index; 5 pages

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Organized according to interview and visit, Vincent talks to various professionals in the field of public health and discusses projects and proposals. As President of the Rockefeller Foundation he is involved in the institutional and administrative duties of the Rockefeller Foundation, International Health Board and China Medical Board. The 1921 diary documents surveying and promotion of medical education in Europe and Asia and the formal opening of Peking Union Medical College.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes: Conference at Gedney Farms Hotel, White Plains, NY; Interviews with Staff Members; Engagements; Memorandum of Conference with President George B. Cuffen, Acadia University, Wolfville, NS; Visit to Art Center, 65-67 East 56 Street, NY; Memorandum on South Manchuria Railway; Memorandum on Plan of Inviting a Group of Japanese Medical Men to United States.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Organized according to interview and visit, Vincent talks to various professionals in the field of public health and discusses projects and proposals. As President of the Rockefeller Foundation he is involved in the institutional and administrative duties of the Rockefeller Foundation, International Health Board and China Medical Board. The 1922 diary documents surveying, promoting and creating public health medical education in Europe and America. He recieves status updates on current Rockefeller Foundation projects from officers. The diary includes: Confidential Memorandum regarding the University situation in Washington.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes: Memorandum of Interview with Doctor Yen; Conference of ERE with (a) WR, and (b) GEV Concerning Nurse Training; Statement of the Situation of the near East Relief; Memorandum of Interview with Prince Songkla; Confidential Memorandum of an Informal Conference Regarding the George Washington University Situation; Memorandum of Interview with Mr. Waldron H. Rand, Dr. Blanche A. Denig, and Miss Tupper; two Conferences in Greenwich; A Yearbook of Medical Education and Public Health; Notes of Trip June 19th to 21st, 1922; Conference on the Far East; Conference on Medical Education in Europe; Memorandum on the Status and Relationships of the Division of Medical Education.

The 1923 diary includes a trip to South America and discussions of malaria program options with Argentine officials. Include is a brief biography of Arturo Alessandri.

In 1926, Vincent travels to Europe to survey medical education and facilities. The during this time aids medical schools, maintains Peking Union Medical College, assists in public health training development, and contributes to nursing education. The diary includes Rev. Eliot White's business card.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This Appendix lists the dates, institutions, and names of individuals interviewed by Miss Walker between 1925 and 1926.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This diary is record of Ms. Walker's meetings with university administrators, social science researchers, and social workers. The diary reveals some of the social science research and innovation that was underway in the United States that was being supported by the Laura Spelman Rockefeller Memorial. The last part of the document describes the proper qualities and training necessary for a social worker as described by the Association of Schools of Professional Social Work.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This diary is a record of Ms. Walker's meetings and interviews with social science researchers and social work experts between January 12 and December 17, 1926. The document reveals Ms. Walker's travels around the country to keep tabs on the projects and innovations in social science taking place in the top universities and institutions for social work and sociology. Her diary gives a status report on some of the largest social science projects across the country as well as the planned expansion of institutions and university programs to continue their work.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This diary is a record of Ms. Walker's meetings and interviews with social science researchers and social work experts between January 24 and December 21, 1927. The document reveals Ms. Walker's travels around the country to keep tabs on the projects and innovations in social science taking place in the top universities and institutions for social work and sociology. Her diary gives a status report on some of the largest social science projects across the country as well as the planned expansion of institutions and university programs to continue their work.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This diary is a record of Ms. Walker's meetings and interviews with social science researchers and social work experts between January 3 and December 14, 1928. The diary records Ms. Walker's travel both within the United States to various universities and social science institutions, as well as a trip to Europe from May 15 through June 9 to visit the modern social science bureaus and university training and research programs. Ms. Walker's destinations in Europe included London, Oxford, Birmingham, Manchester, Liverpool, Edinburgh, Paris, Amsterdam, and Stockholm. Ms. Walker kept a record of her impressions of the calibre and status of social science research and progress in social work both in the United States and abroad over the course of her diary, and her impressions of individual researchers are also recorded.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Index to all diaries between 1929-1937; 7 pages.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This diary records Ms. Walker's meetings and interviews between February 4 and December 9, 1929 with social science researchers and social work experts in the United States and abroad. Ms. Walker's diary references current social science programs in the United States, as well as mentioning programs underway in Europe and China with Rockefeller Foundation support. Ms. Walker's diary is also a record of requests made for monetary support for social work and social science research projects, and provides details about the universities and institutions requesting support as well as the nature of their projects.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This brief diary contains Ms. Walker's notes from interviews with professors and administrators at several top schools and institutes for social work in the United States, dating between January 18 and September 12, 1930. Ms. Walker's provides the requests from the individuals seeking grant support from the Rockefeller Foundation as well as her professional recommendations concerning the schools and personnel involved. Walker includes details about the types of projects being pursued and the level of support they are already receiving.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This brief diary contains Ms. Walker's notes from interviews with professors and administrators at several top schools and institutes for social work primarily in the Southern and Western United States, dating between February 29 and December 30, 1932. Ms. Walker's provides the requests from the individuals seeking grant support from the Rockefeller Foundation as well as her professional recommendations concerning the schools and personnel involved. Walker includes details about the types of projects being pursued and the level of support they are already receiving.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This brief diary contains Ms. Walker's notes from interviews with professors and administrators at several top schools and institutes for social work in the United States, dating between January 10 and December 29, 1933. Ms. Walker's provides the requests from the individuals seeking grant support from the Rockefeller Foundation as well as her professional recommendations concerning the schools and personnel involved. Walker includes details about the types of projects being pursued and the level of support they are already receiving, and this particular diary also references international social science programs being carried out in China and Australia.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This diary records Ms. Walker's meetings and interviews between January 15 and December 31, 1934 with social science researchers and social work experts in the United States and abroad. Ms. Walker's diary references current social science programs in the United States, as well as mentioning programs underway in Europe and the Middle East with Rockefeller Foundation support. Ms. Walker's diary is also a record of requests made for monetary support for social work and social science research projects, and provides details about the universities and institutions requesting support as well as the nature of their projects.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This diary records Ms. Walker's meetings and interviews between January 24 and November 15, 1935 with social science researchers and social work experts in the United States and abroad. Ms. Walker's diary references current social science programs in the United States receiving Rockefeller Foundation support. Ms. Walker's diary is also a record of requests made for monetary support for social work and social science research projects, and provides details about the universities and institutions requesting support as well as the nature of their projects.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This diary records Ms. Walker's meetings and interviews between January 14 and November 5, 1936 with social science researchers and social work experts in the United States and abroad. A large portion of Ms. Walker's diary is devoted to describing the status of the deposed German refugee scholars program and its progress in finding placements for German scholars in American universities. Ms. Walker's diary is also a record of requests made for monetary support for social work and social science research projects, and provides details about the universities and institutions requesting support as well as the nature of their projects. One particularly prominent request in the diary is from McGill University in Montreal, which the Rockefeller Foundation had been providing significant support to since the early 1920s. The entry on McGill provides a noticeable contrast between a heavily Rockefeller-funded institution in Canada and other RF-funded institutions in the US and abroad in terms of the structure and method of social science research, as well as the fiscal responsibility of the university.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This diary records Ms. Walker's meetings and interviews between March 4 and December 17, 1937 with social science researchers and social work experts in the United States and abroad. Ms. Walker's diary references current social science programs in the United States and Europe receiving Rockefeller Foundation support. Ms. Walker's diary is also a record of requests made for monetary support for social work and social science research projects, and provides details about the universities and institutions requesting support as well as the nature of their projects.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This diary records Ms. Walker's meetings and interviews between February 1 and November 16, 1938 with social science researchers and social work experts in the United States and abroad. Ms. Walker's diary references current social science programs in the United States and Europe receiving Rockefeller Foundation support. Ms. Walker's diary is also a record of requests made for monetary support for social work and social science research projects, and provides details about the universities and institutions requesting support as well as the nature of their projects.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This brief diary records Ms. Walker's meetings and interviews between February 20 and November 20, 1939 with social science researchers and social work experts in the United States and abroad. Ms. Walker's diary references current social science programs in the United States, Europe, and Latin America receiving Rockefeller Foundation support. Ms. Walker's diary is also a record of requests made for monetary support for social work and social science research projects, including refugee scholars seeking appointments outside of Europe, and provides details about the universities and institutions requesting support as well as the nature of their projects.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This diary records Ms. Walker's meetings and interviews between January 10 and September 5, 1940 with social science researchers and social work experts in the United States and abroad. Ms. Walker's diary references current social science programs in the United States and Latin America receiving Rockefeller Foundation support, and also alludes to changes in the RF's funding with regards to Europe as a result of World War II. Ms. Walker's diary is also a record of requests made for monetary support for social work and social science research projects, and provides details about the universities and institutions requesting support as well as the nature of their projects.

The diary includes itinerary for trip to Europe May 3- June 13, 1933.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: In 1935, the present Natural Sciences program of the Rockefeller Foundation is to assist in research related to understanding somatic behavior and aid is given to projects in experimental biology. Weaver interviews professionals in the field of natural sciences and tours universities and research facilities to assess Rockefeller Foundation programs in experimental biology. He tours Cambridge for new natural science research programs. The diary includes an itinerary for a European trip 1-27 May 1935.
In 1936, The Rockefeller Foundation Natural Sciences program supports research in endocrinology, genetics and physiology to understand human behavior. The diary also documents fellowships.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Organized according to interview, this diary spans two years of Willits time spent as Director of Social Sciences of the Rockefeller Foundation. The interviews are with various professionals in the field and the topics of conversation include discussions of various projects, grant proposals and fellowships that RF may contribute resources towards. Some of the topics discussed in the journal include implications of war funding, unemployment, labor studies, urban decay, agricultural science, impact of technology and public administration.

controlaccess.subject: World War II
Labor
Social sciences
controlaccess.corpname: Rockefeller Foundation. Division of Social Sciences

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content note
scopecontent.p: Organized according to interview and visit, Willits goes to the Southern United States to survey various southern schools. He interviews members of the college faculty and determines which departments are the strongest. The schools surveyed include University of Virginia, University of North Carolina, Duke University, North Carolina State College and North Carolina College for Negroes. Topics covered in this diary include rural poverty, black studies, populations, and World War II. Included in the diary are copies of "Subject Index to Joseph H. Willits ' Dixie Diary", "Racial Relationships in North Carolina", "Farm Labor Shortages and Maximum Production", "Agricultural Interests of Nonfarm Rural Leaders", "Twenty Years of Migration From Farms" and "Rural Industrialization Creates New Problems"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Organized according to interview and visit, Willits talks to various professionals in the field and discusses projects, grant proposals and fellowships. The Social Science Program is focused on the developing social behavior as a science, applying social science to human problems, developing professionals and establishing a firm basis for social philosophy. Topics in this journal include political behavior, economics and economic history, and international relations. Princeton University's Institute of International Studies is discussed. Willits visits University of Pennsylvania to survey their social science department and attends a conference on Quantitative Description of Technological Change.
